chapter.title: Declarations
chapter.para: Ceylon is a statically typed language. Classes, interfaces, functions, values and aliases must be declared before use. The declaration of a function or value must include an explicit type, or allow the type to be inferred. This allows the compiler to detect many errors, including:

listitem.para: typing errors in identifier names,
references to types which do not exist or are not visible,
references to type members which do not exist or are not visible,
argument lists which do not match parameter lists,
type argument lists which do not match type parameter lists,
incompatible assignment of an expression of one type to a program element of a different type,
evaluation of an attribute or local before its value has been explicitly specified or assigned,
assignment to a non-variable attribute or local,
failure to refine a formal member of a supertype,
refinement of a non-formal, non-default member of a supertype,
switch statements which do not exhaust all cases of an enumerated type.

chapter.para: All declarations follow a general pattern:
chapter.programlisting: Annotation* (keyword | EntryType) (TypeName | MemberName) TypeParams? Params* CaseTypes? ExtendedType? SatisfiedTypes? TypeConstraints? (Definition | ";")
chapter.para: A type parameter does not need an explicit declaration of this form unless it has constraints. In the case that it does have constraints, the constraint declaration does follow the general pattern.
This consistent pattern for declarations, together with the strict block structure of the language, makes Ceylon a highly regular language.

section.title: Compilation unit structure
section.para: A compilation unit is a text file, with the filename extension .ceylon. There are three kinds of compilation unit:

listitem.para: A module descriptor consists of a module declaration. The file must be named module.ceylon.
A package descriptor consists of a module declaration. The file must be named package.ceylon.
A regular compilation unit consists of a list of imported types, values, and functions, followed by a list of toplevel type, value, or function definitions.

section.title: Toplevel and nested declarations
section.para: A toplevel declaration defines a type—a class or interface—or a type alias, or a function or non-variable value.
A toplevel declaration may not be annotated formal, default, or actual.

comment.para: Note: in a future version of the language, we might relax this restriction and support package extension with toplevel member refinement. This can be viewed as a regularization of the language. The practical application is that it would make toplevel invocations and instantiations polymorphic, obviating the need for things like dependency injection.

section.para: Most toplevel declarations contain nested declarations.
Nested declarations are often mixed together with executable statements.

section.title: Imports
section.para: Each compilation unit belongs to exactly one package. Code in one compilation unit may refer to a toplevel declaration in another compilation unit in the same package without explicitly importing the declaration. It may refer to a declaration defined in a compilation unit in another package only if it explicitly imports the declaration using the import statement.
A package is a namespace. A full package name is a period-separated list of all-lowercase identifiers.
For a given package, there may be at most one import statement per compilation unit.

listitem.para: the package belongs to the same module as the compilation unit containing the import statement, or
the package is declared shared in its package descriptor, and the module descriptor of the module containing the import statement explicitly imports the module containing the package.

section.para: Each import statement imports one or more toplevel declarations from the given package, specifying a list of import elements.
An import element is a reference to either:

listitem.para: a single toplevel type (a class, interface, or alias) of the package,
a single toplevel function or value of the package, or
all toplevel declarations of the package.

section.para: An import element may not refer to a non-shared declaration.
An import statement may not contain two import elements which refer to the same declaration.
Note that toplevel declarations in the module ceylon.language never need to be explicitly imported. They are implicitly imported by every compilation unit.

comment.para: Note: an unused import results in a compiler warning.

section.title: Type imports
section.para: An import element that specifies a type name imports the toplevel type with that name from the given package.
A compilation unit may not import two types with the same name.
The import element may be followed by a list of nested import elements, which must specify aliases.

comment.para: Note: as a special exception to the usual language rules, to support interoperation with Java, a nested import element which references a static member of a Java type results in a Ceylon toplevel reference to the static member. In this case, the import element may omit the explicit alias.

section.title: Function and value imports
section.para: An import element that specifies a function or value name imports the toplevel function or value with that name from the given package.
A compilation unit may not import two methods or attributes with the same name.
section.programlisting: import ceylon.math { sqr, sqrt, e, pi }

section.title: Alias imports
section.para: The optional alias clause in a fully-explicit import allows resolution of cross-namespace declaration name collisions.
An alias assigns a different name to the imported declaration, or to a member of the imported declaration. This name is visible within the compilation unit in which the import statement occurs.

comment.para: TODO: Currently, inheritance of two members with the same name from different unrelated types always results in a compile error. We could let you resolve this class of problem by aliasing a member of a type you're importing. This is a bit similar to what Eiffel does, but it would be a lexical thing, scoped to the compilation unit.

section.title: Wildcard imports
section.para: The elipsis ... acts as a wildcard in import statements. An import statement that specifies a wildcard imports all toplevel declarations of the package.

An import statement may specify a list of alias imports followed by a wildcard. In this case, the alias imports are imported with the specified names, and all other toplevel declarations are imported with their declared names.

comment.para: Note: overuse of wildcard imports is discouraged.

section.title: Imported name
section.para: Inside a compilation unit which imports a declaration, the declaration may be referred to by its imported name. For an import element with an alias, the imported name is the alias. For an import element with no alias, or for a wildcard import, the imported name is the original name of the declaration.
An import element may not result in an imported name that is the same as the name of a toplevel declaration contained in the compilation unit in which the import element occurs.
Two import elements occurring in the same compilation unit may not result in the same imported name.

section.title: Parameters
section.para: A function or class declaration may declare parameters. A parameter is a value or function belonging to the declaration it parameterizes. Parameters are distinguished from other values or functions because they occur in a parameter list. A value or function is a parameter of a class or function if it is:

listitem.para: declared inline in a parameter list of the class or function, or
declared normally, within the body of the class or function, but named in a parameter list of the class or function.

section.para: The following class definitions are semantically identical:
section.programlisting: class Person(shared String name, shared variable Integer age=0) {}
section.para: A parameter list may include, optionally:

listitem.para: one or more required parameters,
one or more defaulted parameters (parameters with default values), and/or
a variadic parameter.

section.para: In a parameter list, parameters with default values, if any, must occur after required parameters, if any. The variadic parameter, if any, must occur last.

Every parameter list has a corresponding type, which captures the types of the individual parameters in the list, whether they are defaulted, and whether the last one is variadic. This type is always an subtype of the type Sequential defined in ceylon.language.
The type of an empty parameter list with no parameters is [].

section.title: Required parameters
section.para: A required parameter is a value or callable parameter without a default argument.
Required parameters must occur before any other parameters in the parameter list.

section.title: Defaulted parameters
section.para: A defaulted parameter is a value or callable parameter that specifies a default argument.
section.programlisting: DefaultParam: Param Specifier | CallableParam LazySpecifier | MemberName Specifier
section.para: The = and => specifiers are used throughout the language.
Defaulted parameters must occur after required parameters in the parameter list.
section.programlisting: (Product product, Integer quantity=1, Price pricing(Product p) => p.price)
section.para: The type of the default argument expression of a value parameter must be assignable to the declared type of the parameter. The type of the default argument expression of a callable parameter must be assignable to the return type of the callable parameter.
A parameter of a method or class annotated actual may not specify a default argument. Instead, it inherits the default argument, if any, of the corresponding parameter of the method it refines.

If two parameter lists are almost identical, differing only in that the first parameter of one list is defaulted, and the first parameter of the second list is not defaulted, and P is the the type of the second parameter list then the type of the first parameter list is []|P.

comment.para: TODO: for consistency, we should support f(Float x) => x in a parameter list, when the callable parameter is declared in the body of the function or class.

section.title: Variadic parameters
section.para: A variadic parameter of type T, accepts a sequence of arguments of type T. Inside the function or class, the variadic parameter has type T[].
The variadic parameter must be the last parameter in a parameter list.
The type of a parameter list containing just a variadic parameter of type T is T[].

section.title: Value parameters
section.para: A value parameter is a value named or defined in a parameter list. Like any other value declaration, it has a name, type, and, optionally, annotations.
An argument to a value parameter must be an expression whose type is assignable to the type of the value parameter.

If a value parameter x has type X, and a parameter list has type P, an invariant subtype of Sequential<Y>, then the type of a new parameter list formed by prepending x to the first parameter list is Tuple<X|Y,X,P>, or []|Tuple<X|Y,X,P> if x is defaulted.

section.title: Callable parameters
section.para: A callable parameter is a function named or defined in a parameter list. Like any other function declaration, it has a name, type, one or more parameter lists, and, optionally, annotations.
An argument to a callable parameter must be an expression whose type is assignable to the callable type of the callable parameter.
section.programlisting: ({Value*} values, Comparison by(Value x, Value y))
section.para: If a callable parameter f has callable type Callable<X,A>, and a parameter list has type P, an invariant subtype of Sequential<Y>, then the type of a new parameter list formed by prepending f to the first parameter list is Tuple<Y|Callable<X,A>,Callable<X,A>,P> or []|Tuple<Y|Callable<X,A>,Callable<X,A>,P> if f is defaulted.

section.title: Interfaces
section.para: An interface is a type schema, together with implementation details for some members of the type. Interfaces may not be directly instantiated.

An interface declaration may optionally specify a list of type parameters. An interface declaration may have a list of extended interfaces, a list of metatypes, an enumerated list of subtypes, and/or a list of type constraints.
To obtain a concrete instance of an interface, it is necessary to define and instantiate a class that satisfies the interface, or define an anonymous class that satisfies the interface.
The body of an interface contains:

listitem.para: member (method, attribute, and member class) declarations, and
nested interface and abstract class declarations.

section.para: Unlike the body of a class, method, or attribute, the body of an interface is not executable, and does not directly contain procedural code.

An interface may declare formal methods, attributes, and member classes, and concrete methods, attribute getters, attribute setters, and member classes. An interface may not declare a concrete simple attribute or member object.

A non-abstract nested class declaration is called a member class of the interface. A nested interface or abstract class declaration is not part of the schema of the interface type, and is therefore not considered a member of the interface.

section.title: Interface bodies
section.para: The body of an interface consists purely of declarations. The following constructs may not occur sequentially in the body of an interface:

listitem.para: a statement or control structure,
a method or attribute declaration with a specifier or initializer, or
an object declaration.

section.title: Interface inheritance
section.para: An interface may satisfy any number of other interfaces.

The types listed after the satisfies keyword are supertypes of the interface type. Every extended type must be an interface. An interface may not satisfy the same interface twice (not even with distinct type arguments).
An interface may adapt any number of interfaces, and at most one class.

The types listed after the adapts keyword are also supertypes of the interface type. Every adapted type must be an interface or class. At most one adapted type may be a class. An interface may not adapt the same type twice (not even with distinct type arguments).
An interface inherits all members (methods, attributes and member types) of every supertype.
The schema of the inherited members is formed by substituting type arguments specified in the satisfies or adapts clause.
If an interface satisfies an introduction, the interface must itself be an introduction, and the adapted type of the interface must be a subtype of the adapted type of the introduction it satisfies.
An interface that satisfies a nested interface must be a member of the type that declares the nested interface or of a subtype of the type that declares the nested interface.

section.title: Interfaces with enumerated cases
section.para: The of clause of an interface declaration specifies the list of cases of the interface.
section.programlisting: shared interface Node<Element> of Root<Element> | Branch<Element> | Leaf<Element> { ... }
section.para: The cases may be interfaces, classes, or toplevel anonymous classes. A case may be an abstract class. Each case must be a subtype of the interface type.
If an interface has an of clause, then every subtype of the interface must be subtype of one of the enumerated cases.

section.title: Interface aliases
section.para: An interface declaration which specifies a reference to another interface type defines an interface alias of the specified interface type.
The specified interface type may be a produced type (it may specify type arguments). An interface alias simply assigns an alternative name to the original interface type or produced type.

Interface aliases are not reified types. The metamodel reference for an interface alias—for example, PeopleByName—returns the metamodel object for the aliased interface—in this case, Map<String,Person>.

section.title: Classes
section.para: A class is a stateful, instantiable type. It is a type schema, together with implementation details of the members of the type.

An ordinary class declaration specifies a list of parameters required to instantiate the type, and, optionally a list of type parameters. A class declaration may have a superclass, a list of extended interfaces, a list of metatypes, an enumerated list of subtypes, and/or a list of type constraints.
section.programlisting: ClassHeader: "class" TypeName TypeParams? Params ClassInheritance TypeConstraints?
section.para: To obtain an instance of a class, it is necessary to instantiate the class, or a subclass of the class.
The body of a class contains:

listitem.para: member (method, attribute, and member class) declarations,
nested interface and abstract class declarations, and
instance initialization code.

section.para: The body of a class may contain executable code.

A non-abstract nested class declaration is called a member class of the class. A nested interface or abstract class declaration is not part of the schema of the class type, and is therefore not considered a member of the class.

section.title: Initializer parameters
section.para: Ceylon classes do not support a Java-like constructor declaration syntax. Instead, the body of the class declares initializer parameters. An initializer parameter may be used anywhere in the class body, including in method and attribute definitions.

section.title: Callable type of a class
section.para: The callable type of a class captures the type and parameter types of the class. The callable type is Callable<T,P...>, where T is the class and P... are the parameter types of the class. A sequenced parameter is considered of type T[] where T... is the declared sequenced type.
An abstract class is not callable.

section.title: Initializer section
section.para: The initial part of the body of a class is called the initializer of the class and contains a mix of declarations, statements and control structures. The initializer is executed every time the class is instantiated.
A class initializer is responsible for initializing the state of the new instance of the class, before a reference to the new instance is available to clients.
Within a class initializer, a self reference to the instance being initialized is either:

listitem.para: the expression this, unless contained in a nested class declaration, or
the expression outer, contained in a directly nested class declaration.

section.para: A statement or declaration contained in the initializer of a class may not evaluate an attribute, invoke a method, or instantiate a member class upon the instance being initialized, including upon a self reference to the instance being initialized if the attribute, method, or member class:

listitem.para: occurs later in the body of the class,
is annotated formal or default, or
is inherited from an interface or superclass, and is not refined by a declaration occurring earlier in the body of the class.

section.para: A member class contained in the initializer of a class may not extend a member or nested class of an interface or superclass of the class.
Furthermore, a statement or declaration contained in the initializer of a class may not:

listitem.para: pass a self reference to the instance being initialized as an argument of an instantiation, method invocation, or extends clause expression or as the value of an attribute assignment or specification, or
return a self reference to the instance being initialized.

section.para: Nor may the a class pass a self reference to the instance being initialized as an argument of its own extends clause expression, if any.
Finally, the initializer of a class may not attempt to narrow the type of a self reference to the instance being initialized using the if (is ...) construct.
The initializer of a class is executed after the initializer of its superclass.

section.title: Declaration section
section.para: The remainder of the body of the class consists purely of declarations, similar to the body of an interface. The following constructs may not occur sequentially in the declaration section:

listitem.para: a statement or control structure,
a method or attribute declaration with a specifier or initializer,
an object declaration with a non-empty initializer section, or
an object declaration that directly extends a class other than Object or IdentifiableObject in the module ceylon.language.

section.para: However, the declarations in this second section may freely use this and super, and may invoke any method, evaluate any attribute, or instantiate any member class of the class or its superclasses.

section.title: Class inheritance
section.para: A class may extend another class.
The class specified after the extends keyword is the superclass of the class.
If a class does not explicitly specify a superclass using extends, its superclass is the class IdentifiableObject defined in ceylon.language.
A class may satisfy any number of interfaces.
The interfaces listed after the satisfies keyword are supertypes of the class. A class may not satisfy the same interface twice (not even with distinct type arguments).
A class:

listitem.para: inherits all members (methods, attributes, and member types) of every supertype,
must declare or inherit a member that refines each formal member of every interface it satisfies directly or indirectly, unless the class is declared abstract or formal, and
must declare or inherit a member that refines each formal member of its superclass, unless the class is declared abstract or formal.

section.para: The schema of the inherited members is formed by substituting type arguments specified in the extends or satisfies clause.
If a class satisfies an introduction, the class must be a subtype of the adapted type of the introduction.
The initializer of the superclass of a class is always executed before the initializer of the class whenever the class or any one of its subclasses is instantiated.
A subclass must pass values to each superclass initialization parameter in the extends clause.

A subclass of a nested class must be a member of the type that declares the nested class or of a subtype of the type that declares the nested class. A class that satisfies a nested interface must be a member of the type that declares the nested interface or of a subtype of the type that declares the nested interface.

section.title: Restrictions on user-defined classes
section.para: The following classes may not be directly extended by any class defined outside the module ceylon.language or appear as an upper bound of any type parameter:

listitem.para: Callable, TODO: remove this restriction
Boolean,
Integer and Float,
Character,
String,
Entry, and
Range.

section.para: This allows the compiler to perform certain optimizations upon these types.

section.title: Abstract, formal, and default classes
section.para: A toplevel or nested class may be annotated abstract and is called an abstract class.
If a class annotated shared is a member of a containing class or interface, then the class may be annotated formal and is called a formal member class, or, sometimes, an abstract member class.
An abstract class or formal member class may have formal members.
An abstract class may not be instantiated.
A formal member class may be instantiated.
A class which is not annotated formal or abstract is called a concrete class.
A concrete class may not have formal members.
If a concrete class annotated shared is a member of a containing class or interface, then the class may be annotated default and is called a default member class.
A toplevel class may not be annotated formal or default.
A block local class may not be annotated formal or default.

comment.para: Note: a formal member class would be a reasonably syntax for declaring virtual types. We think we don't need virtual types because they don't offer much that type parameters don't already provide. For example:
comment.programlisting: shared formal class Buffer(Character...) satisfies Sequence<Character>;

section.title: Member class refinement
section.para: Member class refinement is a unique feature of Ceylon, akin to the "factory method" pattern of many other languages.

listitem.para: A member class annotated formal or default may be refined by any class or interface which is a subtype of the class or interface which declares the member class.

A member class annotated formal must be refined by every concrete class which is a subtype of the class or interface that declares the member class, unless the class inherits a concrete member class from a superclass that refines the formal member class.

section.para: A member class of a subtype refines a member class of a supertype if the first member class:

listitem.para: is annotated actual,
has the same name as the member class it refines, and
has a parameter list with the same signature as the member class it refines, after substitution of type arguments specified in the extends or satisfies clause, and either
directly or indirectly extends the member class it refines.

section.para: Finally, the refined member class must be visible to the member class annotated actual.
If a member class is annotated actual, it must refine some class defined by a supertype, and the class it refines must be either formal or default.
A member class may not, directly or indirectly, refine two different member classes not themselves annotated actual.
Then instantiation of the member class is polymorphic, and the actual subtype instantiated depends upon the concrete type of the containing class instance.

section.title: Anonymous classes
section.para: An object declaration makes it possible to define a class, instantiate the class, and declare an attribute referring to the resulting class instance in a single declaration.
An object has an initial lowercase identifier. An object declaration does not specify parameters or type parameters.

An object declaration specifies the name of the attribute and the schema, supertypes, and implementation of the class. It does not specify a type name. Instead, the type has a name assigned internally by the compiler that is not available at compilation time.
An object class:

listitem.para: may not be extended by another class,
may not be abstract or formal, and
may not declare default members.

section.para: If the object is annotated shared, the class is shared.

This class never appears in types inferred by local declaration type inference or generic type argument inference. Instead, occurrences of the class are replaced with the intersection of the extended type with all satisfied types.
An object attribute:

listitem.para: is non-variable, and
may not be refined or declared default.

section.para: If the object is annotated shared, the attribute is shared. If the object is annotated actual, it refines an attribute of a supertype.

Note that a member of an anonymous class that is not annotated actual may only be accessed from within the body of the anonymous class or by directly invoking the object attribute.

section.title: Classes with enumerated cases
section.para: The of clause of a class declaration specifies the list of cases of the class.
The cases may be classes or toplevel anonymous classes. A case may be an abstract class. Each case must be a subclass of the class.
If a class has an of clause, then every subtype of the class must be a subtype of one of the enumerated cases.
A non-abstract class may not have an of clause.

comment.para: TODO: Should we introduce an abbreviated syntax like:
comment.programlisting: shared abstract class Boolean() of case true | case false {}
comment.para: Note that it must be case instead of object to resolve an ambiguity between an annotation and the class body followed by a declaration.

section.title: Class aliases
section.para: A class declaration which specifies a reference to another class type defines a class alias of the specified class type.
The specified class type may be a produced type (it may specify type arguments). A class alias simply assigns an alternative name to the original class type or produced type.
The callable type of the specified type must be assignable to the callable type of the class alias.
Class aliases are not reified types. The metamodel reference for a class alias—for example, People—returns the metamodel object for the aliased class—in this case, ArrayList<Person>.

section.title: Methods
section.para: A method is a callable block of code. Methods may have parameters and may return a value.

All method declarations specify the method name, one or more parameter lists, and, optionally, a list of type parameters. A method declaration may specify a type, called the return type, to which the values the method returns are assignable, or it may specify that the method is a void method—a method which does not return a value. The return type of a void method is considered to be Void. A method declaration may have a list of type constraints.
section.programlisting: MethodHeader: (UnionType | "function" | "void") MemberName TypeParams? Params+ Metatypes? TypeConstraints?
section.para: The Ceylon compiler preserves the names of method parameters.
A method implementation may be specified using either:

listitem.para: a block of code, or
a reference to another method.

section.para: If a method is referenced by a parameter, it must not specify any implementation.

section.title: Callable type of a method
section.para: The callable type of a method captures the return type and parameter types of the method.

listitem.para: The callable type of a method with a single parameter list is Callable<R,P...> where R is the return type of the method, or Void if the method is void, and P... are the parameter types of the method.

The callable type of a method with multiple parameter lists is Callable<O,P...>, where O is the callable type of a method produced by eliminating the first parameter list, and P... are the parameter types of the first parameter list of the method.

section.para: A sequenced parameter is considered of type T[] where T... is the declared sequenced type.

section.title: Methods with blocks
section.para: A method implementation may be a block. If the method is a void method, the block may not contain a return directive that specifies an expression. Otherwise, every conditional execution path of the block must end in a return directive that specifies an expression assignable to the return type of the method.
Note that a method which declares the return type Void is not a void method. A method with declared type Void must return a value of type Void (any value will do).
A non-void block local method may be declared using the keyword function in place of the explicit return type declaration. Then the method return type is inferred:

listitem.para: if the method contains no return directive, then the return type of the method is Bottom (this is the case where the method always terminates in a throw directive), or
otherwise, the return type of the method is the union of all returned expression types of return directives of the method body.

section.para: This method has inferred return type Integer.
This method has inferred return type Float|Integer.
This method has inferred return type Bottom.

section.title: Methods with specifiers
section.para: Alternatively, a method implementation may be an expression that evaluates to a callable object, specified using =. The type of the callable object must be assignable to the callable type of the method.
section.programlisting: Comparison order(String x, String y) = getOrder();
section.para: The callable object expression may not refer to parameters of the method.

A block local method which specifies a callable object expression may be declared using the keyword function in place of the explicit return type declaration. The return type of the method is inferred to be the type of the type argument to the first type parameter of the expression type Callable (the return type).

section.title: Forward declaration of methods
section.para: The declaration of a method may be separated from the specification of the callable object. If a method declaration does have a specifier, named arguments, or a block, and is not annotated formal, it is a forward-declared method.
Every forward-declared method must explicitly specify a type. It may not be declared using the keyword function.
A toplevel method may not be forward-declared. A method of an interface may not be forward-declared.

section.title: Methods with multiple parameter lists
section.para: A method may declare multiple lists of parameters. A method which declares more than one parameter list returns instances of Callable. The compiler infers a nested method whose callable type is formed by taking the method with multiple parameter lists and eliminating the first parameter list.

For a method with n parameter lists, there are n inferred methods. The ith inferred method:

listitem.para: has the same return type as the original declared method,
has the same parameter lists as the declared method, after eliminating the first i-1 parameter lists, and
if i<n, has a body which contains the definition of the i+1th inferred method and simply returns a reference to that method, or
otherwise, if i=n, has the body of the original declared method.

section.para: The first inferred method replaces the original declared method in the definition of the class.

section.title: Formal and default methods
section.para: If a method declaration does have a specifier, named arguments, or a block, and is annotated shared, and is a member of either:

listitem.para: an interface, or
a class annotated abstract or formal,

section.para: then the method declaration may be annotated formal, and is called a formal method, or, sometimes, an abstract method.
A method which is not annotated formal is called a concrete method.
If a concrete method is annotated shared, and is a member of a class or interface, then it may be annotated default and is called a default method.
A method annotated formal may not specify an implementation (a specifier, named arguments, or a block).
A method annotated default may specify an implementation (a specifier, initializer, named arguments, or a block), or may be forward-declared.
Every formal method must explicitly specify a type. It may not be declared using the keyword function.
A toplevel method may not be annotated formal or default.
A block local method may not be annotated formal or default.

section.title: Method refinement
section.para: Methods may be refined, just like in other object-oriented languages.

listitem.para: A class or interface may refine any formal or default method it inherits, unless it inherits a non-formal non-default method that refines the method.
A concrete class must refine every formal method it inherits, unless it inherits a non-formal method that refines the method.

section.para: A method of a subtype refines a method of a supertype if the first method:

listitem.para: is annotated actual,
has the same name as the method it refines,
has the same number of parameter lists, with the same signatures, as the method it refines, after substitution of type arguments specified in the extends or satisfies clause of the class, and

has a return type that is assignable to the return type of the method it refines in the compilation unit containing the method annotated actual, after substitution of type arguments specified in the extends or satisfies clause of the class.

section.para: Finally, the refined method must be visible to the method annotated actual.
If a method is annotated actual, it must refine some method defined by a supertype, and the method it refines must be either formal or default.
A method may not, directly or indirectly, refine two different methods not themselves annotated actual.
Then invocation of the method is polymorphic, and the actual method invoked depends upon the concrete type of the class instance.

For formal methods, a special shortcut form of refinement is permitted. A subclass initializer may simply specify an instance of Callable as the implementation of the method declared by the supertype. No parameter list, return type declaration, or actual annotation is necessary.
Toplevel methods cannot be refined, and so toplevel method invocation is never polymorphic.

section.title: Attributes
section.para: There are three kinds of declarations related to attribute definition:

listitem.para: Simple attribute declarations define state (very similar to a Java field or local variable).
Attribute getter declarations define how the value of a derived attribute is obtained.
Attribute setter declarations define how the value of a derived attribute is assigned.

section.para: Unlike Java fields, Ceylon attribute access is polymorphic and attribute definitions may be refined by subclasses.

All attributes have a type and name. The type of the attribute is specified by the simple attribute declaration or attribute getter declaration. An attribute may be variable, in which case its value can be assigned using the := and compound assignment operators. This is the case for simple attributes explicitly annotated variable, or for attributes with a setter declaration.
Note that an attribute declaration is essentially a method declaration with zero parameter lists. Likewise, an attribute evaluation is essentially a method invocation with zero argument lists.
A toplevel attribute may not be variable.
If a class declares or inherits a variable attribute, it must (directly or indirectly) extend the class IdentifiableObject defined in ceylon.language.

section.title: Simple attributes and locals
section.para: A simple attribute defines state. The value of a simple attribute or local may be specified or initialized as part of the declaration, via a later specification statement or assignment, or via a parameter that references it.

A simple attribute or local annotated variable represents a value that can be assigned multiple times. A simple attribute or local not annotated variable represents a value that can be specified exactly once.
The value of a non-variable attribute is specified using =. A variable attribute may be initialized using the assignment operator :=.
If a simple attribute or local is referenced by a parameter, it must not have an initializer or specifier.
Explicitly typed parameters of classes and methods are also considered to be locals.

A simple attribute declared directly inside the body of a class represents state associated with the instance of the class. Repeated evaluation of the attribute of a particular instance of the class returns the same result until the attribute of the instance is assigned a new value.

A local represents state associated with execution of a particular block of code. A local is really just a special case of a simple attribute declaration, but one whose state is not held across multiple executions of the block of code in which the local is defined.

listitem.para: A simple attribute declared inside a block (the body of a method, attribute getter, attribute setter, or control structure) is a local.
A simple attribute declared inside the body of a class is a local if it is not used inside a method, attribute setter or attribute getter declaration and if it is not annotated shared.
A parameter of a class is a local if it is not used inside a method, attribute setter, or attribute getter declaration.
A parameter of a method is a local.

section.para: A local is a block local declaration—it is visible only to statements and declarations that occur within the lexical scope of the declaration (later in the same block or class body).
The compiler is permitted to optimize block local simple attributes to a simple Java field declaration or local variable. Block local attributes may not be accessed via reflection.

A block local simple attribute with a specifier or initializer may be declared using the keyword value in place of the explicit type declaration. The type of the local or attribute is inferred to be the type of the specifier or initializer expression.

section.title: Forward declaration of simple attributes
section.para: The declaration of a simple attribute or local may be separated from the specification or initialization of its value. If an attribute declaration does have a specifier, initializer, named arguments, or a block, and if it is not annotated formal, it is a forward-declared simple attribute or local.
Every forward-declared simple attribute must explicitly specify a type. It may not be declared using the keyword value.
A toplevel attribute may not be forward-declared. An attribute of an interface may not be forward-declared.

section.title: Attribute getters
section.para: An attribute getter is a callable block of code with no parameters, that returns a value.
An attribute getter defines how the value of a derived attribute is obtained.
If an attribute getter has a matching attribute setter, we say that the attribute is variable. Otherwise we say it is non-variable.
A block local attribute getter may be declared using the keyword value in place of the explicit type declaration. Then the attribute type is inferred:

listitem.para: if the getter contains no return directive, then the type of the attribute is Bottom (this is the case where the getter always terminates in a throw directive), or
otherwise, the type of the attribute is the union of all returned expression types of return directives of the getter body.

section.para: This attribute has inferred type Name.

section.title: Attribute setters
section.para: An attribute setter is a callable block of code that accepts a single value and does not return a value.

An attribute setter defines how the value of a derived attribute is assigned. Every attribute setter must have a corresponding getter with the same name. The getter declaration must directly occur earlier in the body containing the setter declaration.
section.programlisting: shared String name { return join(firstName, lastName); } shared assign name { firstName := first(name); lastName := last(name); }
section.para: A setter may not be annotated shared, default or actual. The visibility and refinement modifiers of an attribute with a setter are specified by annotating the matching getter.

comment.para: TODO: should we require that the corresponding getter be annotated variable?

section.title: Formal and default attributes
section.para: If an attribute declaration does have a specifier, initializer, named arguments, or a block, and is annotated shared, and is a member of either:

listitem.para: an interface, or
a class annotated abstract or formal,

section.para: then the attribute declaration may be annotated formal, and is called a formal attribute, or, sometimes, an abstract attribute.
An attribute which is not annotated formal is called a concrete attribute.
If a concrete attribute is annotated shared, and is a member of a class or interface, then it may be annotated default and is called a default attribute.
An attribute annotated formal may not specify an implementation (a specifier, initializer, named arguments, or a block). Nor may there be a setter for a formal attribute.
An attribute annotated default may specify an implementation (a specifier, initializer, named arguments, or a block), or may be forward-declared.
Every formal attribute must explicitly specify a type. It may not be declared using the keyword function.
A toplevel attribute may not be annotated formal or default.
A block local attribute may not be annotated formal or default.

section.title: Attribute refinement
section.para: Ceylon allows attributes to be refined, just like methods. This helps eliminate the need for Java-style getter and setter methods.

listitem.para: A class or interface may refine any formal or default attribute it inherits, unless it inherits a non-formal non-default attribute that refines the attribute.
A concrete class must refine every formal attribute it inherits, unless it inherits a non-formal attribute that refines the attribute.

section.para: A non-variable attribute may be refined by a simple attribute or attribute getter. A variable attribute may be refined by a variable simple attribute or by an attribute getter and setter pair.

comment.para: TODO: are you allowed to refine a getter or setter without also refining its matching setter or getter?

section.para: An attribute of a subtype refines an attribute of a supertype if the first attribute:

listitem.para: is annotated actual,
has the same name as the attribute it refines,

has a type that is assignable to the type of the attribute it refines in the compilation unit containing the attribute annotated actual, after substitution of type arguments specified in the extends or satisfies clause of the class,
or has exactly the same type as the attribute it refines, after substitution of type arguments specified in the extends or satisfies clause of the class, if the attribute it refines is variable, and
is variable, if the attribute it refines is variable.

section.para: Finally, the refined attribute must be visible to the attribute annotated actual.
If an attribute is annotated actual, it must refine some attribute defined by a supertype, and the attribute it refines must be either formal or default.
An attribute may not, directly or indirectly, refine two different attributes not themselves annotated actual.
A non-variable attribute may be refined by a variable attribute.

comment.para: TODO: Is that really allowed? It could break the superclass. Should we say that you are allowed to do it when you refine an interface attribute, but not when you refine a superclass attribute?

section.para: Then evaluation and assignment of the attribute is polymorphic, and the actual attribute evaluated or assigned depends upon the concrete type of the class instance.

For formal, non-variable attributes, a special shortcut form of refinement is permitted. A subclass initializer may simply specify a value to the attribute declared by the superclass. No type declaration or actual annotation is necessary.

comment.para: TODO: Should we allow this for variable attributes?
TODO: Why not also allow this for default attributes and methods?

section.para: Toplevel attributes cannot be refined, and so toplevel attribute evaluation and assignment is never polymorphic.

section.title: Program element annotations
section.para: Declarations may be preceded by a list of annotations. An annotation is an initial lowercase identifier, optionally followed by an argument list. A list of annotations does not require punctuation between the individual annotations in the list.
For an annotation with no arguments, or with only literal-valued positional arguments, the parentheses around, and commas between, the positional arguments may be omitted.
section.programlisting: doc "The user login action" by "Gavin King" "Andrew Haley" throws (DatabaseException, "if database access fails") seeAlso (LogoutAction.logout) scope (session) action { description="Log In"; url="/login"; } shared deprecated
section.para: An annotation is an invocation of a toplevel method that occurs when the program element is loaded by the virtual machine. The return type of this toplevel method is called the annotation type of the annotation. Invocation of the toplevel method is called evaluation of the annotation. The toplevel method may not declare type parameters.
section.programlisting: shared Scope scope(Scope s) { return s; }
shared Todo todo(String text) { return Todo(text); }

section.title: Annotation arguments
section.para: An annotation may be specified at a program element using any one of three forms.

listitem.para: Using a positional argument invocation of the method:
Using a named argument invocation of the method:
Or using the special abbreviated form for annotations with literal value arguments:

section.title: Annotation types
section.para: The annotation type of an annotation must be a subtype of the interface ConstrainedAnnotation defined in the package ceylon.language.metamodel. Any type which is a subtype of ConstrainedAnnotation is called an annotation type.
The type arguments of this interface express constraints upon how annotations which return the annotation type occur.
There are only two direct subtypes of ConstrainedAnnotation:
section.programlisting: shared interface OptionalAnnotation<out Value, in ProgramElement> satisfies ConstrainedAnnotation<Value,Value?,ProgramElement> given Value satisfies Annotation<Value> given ProgramElement satisfies Annotated {}

shared interface SequencedAnnotation<out T, in ProgramElement> satisfies ConstrainedAnnotation<Value,Value[],ProgramElement> given Value satisfies Annotation<Value> given ProgramElement satisfies Annotated {}
section.para: If A is an annotation type then:

listitem.para: If A is a subtype of OptionalAnnotation, at most one annotation of annotation type A may occur at a given program element.
If A is a subtype of SequencedAnnotation, multiple annotations of annotation type A may occur at a given program element.

If A is a subtype of OptionalAnnotation<A,P>, or SequencedAnnotation<A,P> then an annotation of annotation type A may not occur at a program element whose metamodel expression type is not assignable to P.

section.para: It is perfectly acceptable for multiple toplevel methods to return the same annotation type.

comment.para: TODO: should we let an annotation return multiple instances of an annotation type (A[] where A is an annotation type).

section.title: Annotation values
section.para: An annotation value is the value returned when an annotation is evaluated. We may obtain the annotation values of all annotations of a given annotation type that occur at a given program element by passing the annotation type and program element metamodel reference to the method annotations() defined in the package ceylon.language.metamodel.

section.title: Declaration modifiers
section.para: The following annotations are compiler instructions:

listitem.para: shared specifies that a declaration is visible outside of the package or body in which it occurs, or that a package is visible outside the module it belongs to.
abstract specifies that a class cannot be instantiated.
formal specifies that a member does not specify an implementation and must therefore be refined by every concrete subclass.
default specifies that a method, attribute, or member class may be refined by subtypes.
actual indicates that a method, attribute, or member type refines a method, attribute, or member type defined by a supertype.
variable specifies that an attribute or local may be assigned.

deprecated indicates that a method, attribute or type is deprecated. It accepts an optional String argument. The compiler produces a warning when compiling code that depends upon a deprecated program element.
literal specifies that a class or interface has a single quoted literal format.

section.para: The following annotation is a hint to the compiler that lets the compiler optimize compiled bytecode for non-64 bit architectures:

listitem.para: small specifies that a value of type Integer, Integer or Float contains 32-bit values.

section.para: By default, Integer and Float are assumed to represent 64-bit values.

comment.para: TODO: should we have final to specify that a class may not be extended?
TODO: how hard would it be to add a recursive annotation to force the compiler to optimize a tail-recursive method or getter?

section.title: Refinement modifiers
section.para: A declaration may not be annotated both formal and default.
If a declaration is annotated formal, default, or actual then it must also be annotated shared.

section.title: Visibility and name resolution
section.para: Classes, interfaces, methods, attributes, locals, parameters and type parameters have names. Occurrence of a name in code implies a hard dependency from the code in which the name occurs to the schema of the named declaration. We say that a class, interface, method, attribute, parameter or type parameter is visible to a certain program element if its name may occur in the code that defines that program element.
The visibility of a declaration depends upon where it occurs, and upon whether it is annotated shared. A toplevel or member declaration may be annotated shared:

listitem.para: If a toplevel declaration is annotated shared, it is visible wherever the package that contains it is visible. Otherwise, a toplevel declaration is visible only to code in the package containing its compilation unit.

If a member declaration is annotated shared, it is visible wherever the class or interface that contains it is visible. Otherwise, a declaration that occurs directly inside a class or interface body is visible only inside the class or interface declaration.

section.para: A parameter, type parameter, or declaration that occurs directly inside a block (the body of a method, attribute getter or attribute setter) may not be annotated shared.

listitem.para: A parameter or type parameter is visible only inside the declaration to which it belongs.
A declaration that occurs directly inside a block is visible only inside the block.

section.para: A nested declaration not annotated shared is called a block local declaration.

comment.para: TODO: Should we allow you to limit the effect of the shared annotation by specifying a containing program element or package? Program element is easy, since we already have a typesafe syntax for referring to a method or type: shared(ContainingClass). Package is a bit tricker. Of course we could use a single quoted literal, shared('org.example.containing.package'), but perhaps this would justify introducing a literal package name syntax: shared(:org:example:containing:package).

section.para: We say that a produced type is visible to a certain program element if it is formed from type parameters and types whose declarations are visible to the program element. For shared declarations:

listitem.para: The type of an attribute must be visible everywhere the attribute itself is visible.
The return type of a method must be visible everywhere the method itself is visible.
The satisfied interfaces of a class or interface must be visible everywhere the class or interface itself is visible.
The superclass of a class must be visible everywhere the class itself is visible.

section.title: Documentation
section.para: The following annotations are instructions to the documentation compiler:

listitem.para: doc specifies the description of a program element, in Markdown format text.
by specifies the authors of a program element.
license specifies the URL of the license under which a module or package is distributed.
see specifies a related member or type.
throws specifies a thrown exception type.
tagged specifies classifying named tags.

section.para: The String arguments to the deprecated, doc, throws and by annotations are parsed by the documentation compiler as Markdown-format content.
These annotations are defined in the package ceylon.language.documentation.
